bibl.title: Letter from Walter M. Simpson to Philip Showalter Hench, June 11, 1941

div1.p: Simpson comments on Kissinger's stroke and requests a photograph of the Cornwell painting unveiling. He informs Hench that two men connected with medical journals are eager to publish Hench's speech on the yellow fever story, which he delivered at the unveiling ceremony.

div1.head: Letter from Walter M. Simpson to Philip Showalter Hench, June 11, 1941
div1.opener:
KETTERING INSTITUTE FOR MEDICAL RESEARCH
THE MIAMI VALLEY HOSPITAL
DAYTON, OHIO
June 11, 1941
WALTER M. SIMPSON, M.D., F.A.C.P., DIRECTOR
H. WORLEY KENDELL, M.D., ASSOCIATE DIRECTOR
DONALD L. ROSE, M.D., RESEARCH ASSOCIATE
Doctor Philip S. Hench,
The Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minnesota.
My dear Phil:
div1.p:
Many thanks for your letters of June seventh and June ninth. It
was a real shock to learn that dear old Kissinger had suffered a stroke
two days after the memorable meeting in Cleveland. June and I were
thrilled to meet him. He seemed such a simple, genuine and lovable
character. Under the circumstances, it will probably be impossible to
get an autographed photograph of him. If, as we all hope, he does re-
cover I wish you would keep it in mind. Even though we should succeed
in getting his picture I would like to have a print of the photograph
of you, Mr. Cornwell, Miss Blossom Reed, and Mr. Kissinger, in front
of Mr. Cornwell's painting.

I will, of course, send a note to Mrs. Kissinger, telling of our
enjoyment in meeting him and of our hope for his recovery.

I enclose a cutting from the Dayton Herald of June fifth. Appar-
ently, this went to newspapers all over the country over the wirephoto.

I saw Paul Hoeber just after we left the luncheon. He was greatly
interested in the talk you gave at the unveiling ceremony. He indicated
that he was eager to have it for the Annals of Medical History. He took
a copy of your address with him. That evening I had dinner with Morris
Fishbein. I told Morris about your talk and he stated at once: “I must
have the manuscript for Hygeia. It is just the kind of story for lay
people.” I told Morris that I would pass the word to you. It occurs
to me that a condensation of the paper would be ideal for publication
in Hygeia, rather than in the Annals of Medical History. I leave the
matter to your good judgment. I do not feel that such a condensation
would conflict in the least with the publication of a monograph. It is
a thrilling story and you have treated it with just the right touch. I
do not know of any story in the whole realm of medical history to compare
do not know of any story in the whole realm of medical history to compare
with it.

June and I are more than ever in your debt for your thoughtfulness
in inviting us to attend the luncheon as your guests.
June joins me in sending affectionate greetings from House to House.
div1.closer: Always yours, Walter M. Simpson, M. D. WMS/B
